ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The professor would host live lectures but would also record them for later rewatching which was very helpful. There were also weekly quizzes.
If you read over the syllabus, this course is based on a mastery system. I think this system works really well for online learning.
N/a
Recorded lecture and office hours.
problem sets on own and recorded lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ability to problem solve and a better grasp of calculus.
I learned basic calculus (derivatives, integrals...) which will help me on the rest of my pre-med path, especially as I get ready to take Physics next.
Graphing and interpreting single variable equations
I learned derivatives specifically and the importance of demonstrating the algebra or calculus used to arrive at a solution.
I learned about what types of resources Yale offers to their students.
I learned calculus and how to do better algebra

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths- the grading and assignments were fair and allowed students an opportunity to master and understand every topic covered.
no real weaknesses I enjoyed the structure and content of this course!

For me, it's harder to learn math when you're not physically in the same room as the professor. Besides that, this course was great. Offered many resources and a fair grading system to help us get the grade we wanted.
The strengths were that you could meet any time for office hours with the professor and he would respond to emails extremely promptly.

Strengths - Mastery based grading system meant that it was very clear what areas we needed to improve on and what areas we were proficient in.
Weaknesses - Some sections had great amounts of inconsistency between what was taught in class and the material we learned and were tested on as set forth by the course director. Depends on the professor - Edwards did a pretty good job of sticking to the curriculum, but I heard that some other professors did not do a very good job of it.
A discussion section may be beneficial

Strengths are the helpfulness of the professor,  his useful office hours, and the helpful insight of the professor. To improve the course I would offer more in class examples that are similar to the problem sets and Hams.
My strengths were in the first half of the course however integrals and the last chapter was difficult with me.
the format with mastery was difficult for virtual learning because it sometimes was hard to grasp topics fully when a lot of learning was done alone

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The increased amount of office hours really helped.
The live sessions and office hours were extremely helpful.
More chances for office hours. Sometimes I could not make the scheduled time.
could do more practice problems during class

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Its a great introductory course to calculus. Fair assignments. TA's and Professors were very approachable.
Yes if you need math for your major. If you're just looking for a QR, then no
If you need a Calc 1 class this is the class for you! They explain all the concepts super clearly and it's really easy to ask for help when you don't understand.

Overall, I would recommend the course. Probably expect to either do a good bit of self studying or be willing to reach out to the professor in office hours, because class time sometimes was less useful than it could have been, but overall the course went well.
Yes, better than other math courses Ive heard about.
Yes, I would recommend this course because it equips you with the basics of Calc that are necessary for higher level math and Econ classes.
Yes because it gives you a good background of fundamental calculus.
no, because the format of mastery made the class confusing
